channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: How to Celebrate Juneteenth
item.description: This year, amid protests against police brutality and structural racism toward black Americans, some lean into the joy of tradition as resistance. Others say recognition is not enough.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus

item.title: How Reparations for Slavery Became a 2020 Campaign Issue
item.description: In 1865, formerly enslaved people were promised 40 acres of land and, later, a mule. More than 150 years since then some politicians are trying to make good on a version of that promise.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg

item.title: Park Police Head Had Been Accused of Illegal Searches and Unreliable Testimony
item.description: The force was centrally involved in the authorities’ use of pepper spray to clear protesters from a park near the White House this month.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Goldstein and Katie Benner
item.media:description: U.S. Park Police officers near the White House early this month.

item.title: Who Is Opal Lee? Her Campaign to Make Juneteenth a Holiday
item.description: The 93-year-old activist and lifelong Texan has campaigned to make June 19 a national holiday for years.
item.dc:creator: Julia Carmel
item.media:description: Opal Lee at Fort Worth City Hall on June 19, 2015, the day also known as Juneteenth.

item.title: Scientists Take Aim at Another Coronavirus Study in a Major Journal
item.description: A report on masks relied on unfounded assumptions, researchers charged, and the authors were permitted to choose their own reviewers.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
National Academies of the United States
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Experts said the paper’s conclusion that masks prevent viral transmission was supported by other studies, but that the methodology was deeply flawed.

item.title: Facebook Removes Trump Ads Displaying Symbol Used by Nazis
item.description: Nazis used a red triangle to classify political prisoners during World War II. The Trump campaign said the red triangle in its Facebook ads was associated with antifa, a claim experts rejected.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Facebook said it removed the Trump campaign’s ads for “violating our policy against organized hate.”

item.title: ‘Dreamers’ Get a Reprieve on DACA
item.description: Thousands of young people who were in the country illegally as children have been caught in legal limbo. A new Supreme Court ruling gave them a temporary win.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of DACA celebrate in front of the Supreme Court in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Mitch McConnell Nears His Benchmark
item.description: With confirmation of his protégé to a powerful court, the G.O.P. leader is on the brink of his goal to fill all vacancies at the appellate level by year’s end.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:description: “It is a source of considerable satisfaction,” Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said in an interview about the judicial achievement.

item.title: You May Have Antibodies After Coronavirus Infection. But Not for Long.
item.description: Antibodies to the virus faded quickly in asymptomatic people, scientists reported. That does not mean immunity disappears.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Medical workers helped carry a patient who recovered from Covid-19 from a hospital in Wuhan, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ex-Pentagon Analyst Sentenced to 30 Months in Leak Case
item.description: The former counterterrorism analyst had pleaded guilty to sharing classified information with reporters about foreign weapon systems.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alexandria Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The arrest of Henry Kyle Frese, a former Defense Intelligence Agency analyst, was part of the Trump administration’s efforts to crack down on illegal leaks of classified information.

item.title: Where Black Lives Matter Protesters Stream Live Every Day: Twitch
item.description: The Amazon-owned site, known for showing video game play, has become a hub for airing the sit-ins and marches over racial inequality.
item.dc:creator: Kellen Browning
item.media:description: Shawn Whiting began streaming Black Lives Matter protests late last month and sometimes broadcasts on Twitch for four hours a day.

item.title: E.P.A. Won’t Regulate Toxic Compound Linked to Fetal Brain Damage
item.description: The move was widely expected after The New York Times reported last month that the agency’s administrator had decided to effectively defy a court order.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.media:description: Andrew Wheeler, the E.P.A. administrator, during a Senate committee hearing last month.

item.title: Defense Secretary Will Assess How to Promote More Minorities in Military
item.description: The announcement comes as the military is working through issues on race that reflect the larger forces sweeping the country.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper said in an announcement Thursday that the military is “not immune to the forces of bias and prejudice — whether visible or invisible, conscious or unconscious.”

item.title: PG&E Ordered to Pay $3.5 Million Fine for Causing Deadly Fire
item.description: A judge approved an agreement between the California utility and a prosecutor after hearing from survivors whose loved ones were among the 84 people killed in the Camp Fire.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: A photo of Paul Ernest, one of 84 people killed in the Camp Fire in 2018, was on display at a sentencing hearing for Pacific Gas & Electric.

item.title: Scientists Predict Scorching Temperatures to Last Through Summer
item.description: Hotter than normal temperatures are expected across almost all of the United States into September, government researchers said.
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain and John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antjuan Durand, a chef, tried to cool off while grilling at Bert’s Marketplace in Detroit, Mich., last summer.

item.title: DACA Explained: What is it?
item.description: Here’s what you need to know about a policy that protected from deportation people who were brought into the United States as children.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Dickerson
item.category: Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)
item.media:credit: Jose Luis Magana/Agence France-Presse via Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators at the Supreme Court in November 2019, a few days before the court heard arguments about the status of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program.

item.title: Promotion in Jeopardy for Army Officer Who Challenged Trump on Ukraine
item.description: Military officials fear the White House may retaliate against Lt. Col. Alexander Vindman for his testimony in the House impeachment inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Alexander S. Vindman testified in the House impeachment inquiry last year.

item.title: Why Can’t I Appreciate the Confederate Flag and Also Condemn Racism?
item.description: A reader does not understand why her children take issue with her nostalgia for Civil War iconography.
item.dc:creator: Philip Galanes

item.title: Climate Change Tied to Pregnancy Risks, Affecting Black Mothers Most
item.description: Women exposed to high temperatures or air pollution are more likely to have premature, underweight or stillborn babies, a look at 32 million U.S. births found.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:description: Researchers looked at data from studies covering more than 32 million births from 2007 to 2019.

item.title: De Blasio Says NYC Will Enter Phase 2 of Reopening on Monday
item.description: As many as 300,000 workers are expected to get back to work as outdoor dining, in-store shopping and office work resumes.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms/The New York Times
item.media:description: In the next phase of reopening restaurants will be allowed to offer service at outdoor seating.

item.title: Trump Can’t Immediately End DACA, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: The program, Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, protects people brought to the United States as children by shielding them from deportation and letting them work.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the DACA program celebrated Thursday in front of the Supreme Court.

item.title: How to Buy a Bike
item.description: These days, with limits on public transportation and daily protests, cyclists dominate cities around the country. Here’s how to become one.
item.dc:creator: John Herrman
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times

item.title: Live Updates: Garrett Rolfe Surrenders in Rayshard Brooks Killing
item.description: Garrett Rolfe, who was fired after the shooting and now faces criminal charges including felony murder, turned himself in on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial on Wednesday outside the Wendy’s restaurant where Rayshard Brooks was shot and killed.

item.title: How Skateboarding Can Help Fight Racism
item.description: Thursday: A recent U.S.C. study about the sport takes on new urgency.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: People riding skateboards down Market Street in San Francisco last week in a Black Lives Matter protest.

item.title: Joe Biden Begins First General Election TV Ad Blitz
item.description: The $15 million advertising effort will target six fall battlegrounds, all states that President Trump carried in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. raised $80.8 million in May, a major sign his financial situation has improved.

item.title: Jean Kennedy Smith Dies at 92; Helped Forge Peace in Northern Ireland
item.description: The last surviving sibling in a family that wrote itself into U.S. history, she was the first Kennedy woman of her generation to take on a serious political role.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Larry C. Morris/The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean Kennedy Smith with her husband, Stephen E. Smith, left, in 1976 during a benefit for the Special Olympics at the Pierre hotel in Manhattan. Years later she was named ambassador to Ireland by President Bill Clinton at the behest of her brother Edward.

item.title: Bolton, Belatedly, Tells All
item.description: House Democrats could use a time machine just about now: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

item.title: A College Reality Check
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The University of Kentucky faces a complicated balancing act as it considers the risks of reopening its campus for 30,000 students and 18,000 employees.

item.title: Unemployment Claims Show Another 1.5 Million Filings: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:description: Hertz said its board had decided that it was “in the best interests of the company” to scrap the equity sale.

item.title: Covid-19 Worldwide: Live Updates on Cases and Deaths
item.description: Seventy-seven nations have seen a growth in new cases over the past two weeks. Texas plans to let schools reopen, despite a recent uptick. California’s governor orders people to wear masks as the state saw a one-day record.
item.media:description: A Covid burial in Santiago, Chile, this week.

item.title: What It Takes to Reopen a Small Business Right Now
item.description: Masks are just the start. Entrepreneurs around the U.S. are figuring out what to do as they go, and hoping that they can make it work.
item.dc:creator: Amy Haimerl
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pickled Fish, a restaurant owned by Adrift Hospitality in Long Beach, Wash., has reopened with socially distanced seating.

item.title: How the Trump Campaign’s Plans for a Triumphant Rally Went Awry
item.description: Instead of offering President Trump a glide path back into the campaign season, Saturday’s rally in Tulsa has become yet another flash point for a candidate who has repeatedly displayed insensitivity about race.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni, Maggie Haberman and Reid J. Epstein
item.media:description: Brad Parscale, President Trump’s campaign manager, selected the date and location of the campaign’s comeback rally.

item.title: ‘Power to the People’: Detroit Students Preserve This Moment in Paint
item.description: A mural on the city’s main thoroughfare that honors the spirit of the protests was the result of a contest in which students chose their favorite rendering, and helped paint it.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Sylvia Jarrus for The New York Times
item.media:description: Teenagers listened to instructions before starting work on a huge street mural reading “Power to the People” along Woodward Avenue in Detroit.

item.title: 5 Takeaways From John Bolton’s Book "The Room Where it Happened"
item.description: “The Room Where It Happened” describes Mr. Bolton’s 17 turbulent months at President Trump’s side through a multitude of crises and foreign policy challenges.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.category: The Room Where It Happened: A White House Memoir (Book)
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Fiona Hill, John R. Bolton’s former Russia adviser, during a House impeachment hearing last year in Washington.

item.title: Michael Pack, Chief of Media Agency, Dismisses Heads of U.S. News Outlets
item.description: The moves by Michael Pack, an ally of Steve Bannon appointed by President Trump, raised concerns that the news organizations would become partisan.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:description: Michael Pack, the new chief of the United States Agency for Global Media, replaced bipartisan board members with right-leaning appointees.

item.title: Arthur Ashe Statue in Virginia Vandalized With ‘White Lives Matter’
item.description: The statue of Mr. Ashe, a Richmond native, was defaced with “WLM” and “White Lives Matter.” The letters “BLM,” for Black Lives Matter, were spray-painted over the initial graffiti.
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Bob Brown/Richmond Times-Dispatch, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The letters “BLM,” probably meaning “Black Lives Matter,” cover the “WLM” for “White Lives Matter” at the base of the Arthur Ashe Monument in Richmond, Va., on Wednesday.

item.title: Before Crash That Killed Kobe Bryant, Helicopter Service Raised Weather Concerns
item.description: The pilot texted “weather looking OK” on the morning of the crash, which killed all nine people aboard the Sikorsky S-76B helicopter, according to newly released documents.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Kyle Grillot for The New York Times
item.media:description: Memorabilia and flowers left near the Staples Center in January to pay respects to Kobe Bryant.

item.title: Justice Dept. Escalates Legal Fight With Bolton Over Book
item.description: The Trump administration asked a judge to order the former national security adviser to stop publication of his memoir even as explosive details emerged.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: The Room Where It Happened: A White House Memoir (Book)
item.media:description: The Justice Department also asked to be able to seize any proceeds from the coming book by President Trump’s former national security adviser John R. Bolton.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Patients sometimes face a long, difficult recovery from the virus.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: With the Federal Health Megaphone Silent, States Struggle With a Shifting Pandemic
item.description: As state and local governments confront a new wave of coronavirus infections, President Trump is sending mixed messages and Washington’s public health bully pulpit has gone silent.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg, Noah Weiland, Sarah Mervosh and David E. Sanger
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A staff member was tested for the coronavirus at a nursing home in the Bronx last week. Cases in New York are declining.

item.title: What Joe Biden’s Event Was Like
item.description: As one candidate plays to a nearly empty room, another prepares for a rally with health risks.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: 5 Years After Charleston Church Massacre, City Says Calhoun Statue Will Go
item.description: Five years after the mass shooting at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, officials in Charleston, S.C., announced a plan to remove a monument to the prominent slavery defender John C. Calhoun.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: A statue of John C. Calhoun looms over a public park in Charleston, S.C., during an arts festival in 2016.

item.title: Delbert Africa, 74, Convicted in Radical Group’s Clash With Police, Dies
item.description: As a member of Move, he spent four decades in prison and was released in January. His beating by Philadelphia police officers in 1978 was broadcast nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger

item.title: On L.G.B.T.Q. Rights, a Gulf Between Trump and Many Republican Voters
item.description: As more Republicans say they support at least some L.G.B.T.Q. protections, President Trump and party leaders continue to stand in opposition and particularly target transgender Americans.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Giovanni Russonello and Isabella Grullón Paz
item.media:description: A protester held up a transgender flag in October outside the Supreme Court. This week, the justices ruled in favor of L.G.B.T.Q. protections against workplace discrimination.
